text:
Thanks <@U01SCPDTV5J>. I appreciate that. Just to clarify, will the win command I posted have the effect of only considering win markets?

Before I went to bed last night, I put the following filters in place:

```strategy = TestStrategy(
    market_filter={"markets": get_markets("PRO"),
    "listener_kwargs": {"seconds_to_start": 60},
    "market_types": ["WIN"]},
    max_order_exposure=1000,
    max_selection_exposure=105,
)```
The program is still running (I went to bed before midnight).

I'll  have a go at adding multiprocessing to my code (though it might be beyond my current Python abilities).

For now though, I suspect that my best bet might be to remove all but 1 day of the month of data from the dataset. If I find an approach that yields a profit on one day, I can test it on a larger dataset.

Jeff

text:
<@UPMUFSGCR> as the <@U013K4VNB6D> identified the programming language, you can do as well see something like this:

do! Async.Parallel (jobs, maxDegreeOfParallelism = 5) |> Async.Ignore

as my app is desktop app, and I wanted to show updates on the screen/grid control during backtesting I used  maxDegreeOfParallelism = 5, as after test on a market is done results are updated, so there is quite a lot of switches to UI thread context, eliminating this UI updates, and setting maxDegreeOfParallelism = 8 as I have got PC with 4 cores and 8 logical processors, my backtesting could be even quicker, but there is no point of doing it for me now. I can write just console app for backtesting, but the desktop app as well analyze and presents data different ways.

text:
Do you think the reason that you don't get offers to help with source code is simply because F# is a pretty niche language that few people are able to program in?

For example, when I search for F# jobs in the UK on Indeed, I get 75 ads, whereas when I search for C# jobs, I get 8,064 ads.

text:
When an order is placed, the code in `class BetfairExecution(BaseExecution > def execute_place` seems to do nothing when the response order status is "EXECUTION_COMPLETE" and waits for this order status to be processed via the flumine queue; specifically in `process.py > def process_current_order` which sets the order status to `OrderStatus.EXECUTION_COMPLETE`.

Given that the API immediate response is the quickest way to determine an order status, I would have thought that an EXECUTION_COMPLETE order would be set thus in `class BetfairExecution(BaseExecution > def execute_place` so that a strategy knows at the earliest possible time that an order is done'n'dusted.

Caveat: I am learning BFLW and Flumine so that above may be gibberish.

seems to do nothing when the response order status is "EXECUTION_COMPLETE" and waits for this order status to be processed via the flumine queue; specifically in
process.py > def process_current_order
which sets the order status to
OrderStatus.EXECUTION_COMPLETE

.

Given that the API immediate response is the quickest way to determine an order status, I would have thought that an EXECUTION_COMPLETE order would be set thus in
class BetfairExecution(BaseExecution > def execute_place

so that a strategy knows at the earliest possible time that an order is done'n'dusted.

Caveat: I am learning BFLW and Flumine so that above may be gibberish.

text:
I started running a back test about 90 minutes ago.

I removed all but one day's data out of a month of greyhound data that I purchased from Betfair. I haven't yet added multiprocessing, but I have put in filters to exclude non-win markets and data > 61 seconds from the off.

The program is still running, meaning it would take well over 24 hours to process the whole month's data.

I've put my code on GitHub: <https://github.com/JeffW12345/betfair-backtesting>. Any suggestions on improving its speed would be much appreciated.

Thanks,

Jeff

text:
100 markets:

```start time = 07/09/2021 11:25:17
Total profit post-commission: 468.04

finish time = 07/09/2021 11:26:44```
Bugfix in the strategy, logging set to CRITICAL and this fix to the get_markets

```def get_markets(data_dir):
    markets = []
    for dir_, _, files in os.walk(data_dir):
        for file_name in files:
            rel_file = os.path.join(data_dir, file_name)
            markets.append(rel_file)
    return markets ```

                    `order2 = trade.create_order(`
                    `side="LAY",`
                    `order_type=LimitOrder(2, self.context["stake"],`
                        `persistence_type="LAPSE"),`
                    `notes=OrderedDict(underround=round(underround, 4))`
                    `)`
                    `market.place_order(order2)`
`def _calculate_underround(runners: list) -> float:`
    `return sum(`
        `[`
            `1 / r.ex.available_to_lay[0]["price"]`
            `for r in runners`
            `if r.ex.available_to_lay`
        `]`
    `)`

text: Your not storing your market files on a network drive or similar are you?

elements.text: Your not storing your market files on a network drive or similar are you?

text:
No, they are stored in a folder on my C drive.

Because the files are in different folders within the PRO folder, I modified the get_markets method, as I was getting a 'file not found' error message:

```def get_markets(data_dir):
    markets = []
    for dir_, _, files in os.walk(data_dir):
        for file_name in files:
            dirName = Path(dir_).absolute()
            rel_file = os.path.join(dirName, file_name)
            markets.append(rel_file)
    return markets```
I wouldn't have thought that would slow things down, though?

Apart from that, you and I were running the same code.

The fact that you guys aren't seeing any major errors or omissions suggests to me the the slow speed is hardware-related?

text:
I've included it in my market filter:

```strategy = TestStrategy(
    market_filter={"markets": get_markets("PRO"),
                   "listener_kwargs": {"seconds_to_start": 61},
                   "market_types": ["WIN"]},
    max_order_exposure=1000,
    max_selection_exposure=105,
)```

)

text: Or just put your `now = datetime.now()`  after you have instantiated the strategy

now = datetime.now()
after you have instantiated the strategy

text: Also, set your logging level to CRITICAL.  You're going to be printing out a lot of messages with it set to INFO, especially as you're not checking the exposure in your strategy, so you're going to get lots of STRATEGY_EXPOSURE messages.

elements.text: Also, set your logging level to CRITICAL.  You're going to be printing out a lot of messages with it set to INFO, especially as you're not checking the exposure in your strategy, so you're going to get lots of STRATEGY_EXPOSURE messages.

text:
Thanks guys.

Progress at last (I think!). :slightly_smiling_face:

I just rebooted my computer and tried again.

This is a bit more like it!

program start time =  07/09/2021 15:19:17
framework start time =  07/09/2021 15:19:17
finish time = 07/09/2021 15:19:21

That's more like it! :grin:

I'm guessing that adding CRITICAL was made the difference. Liam also suggested adding CRITICAL, but I didn't know what it meant (though I should have asked! :slightly_smiling_face:).

When I do 100 markets, I get:

program start time =  07/09/2021 15:30:56
framework start time =  07/09/2021 15:30:56
finish time = 07/09/2021 15:33:16

So that's 2 minutes 40. So that's a market every 1.6 seconds.

So I'd still be looking at 7 hours for a full month of data (~16,000 markets). However, for a day, I'd be looking at about a quarter of an hour, which is viable. And if I get a profit over a day's trading, I can leave my computer running overnight to see if the edge holds over a month.

Thanks everyone for being so supportive and for your patience. :slightly_smiling_face:

Does the file beginning 2 contain all of the data in the files in that folder starting 1.1?

If so, could I speed things up by removing files beginning 2 from consideration?

text: <@U02B19879K9> has joined the channel
Can anyone tell me when and why one would use paper trading in flumine :scroll:?

elements.text: Can anyone tell me when and why one would use paper trading in flumine

text: To check everything's working as expected before you go live

elements.text: To check everything's working as expected before you go live

text: I think the standard process for developing a strategy is: analysis -> backtest -> paper trade -> live...

elements.text: I think the standard process for developing a strategy is: analysis -> backtest -> paper trade -> live...

text: Thanks <@U01MPC0GUK1>  So I guess next question is what does paper trading offer you that a backtest doesn't?

elements.text: Thanks
So I guess next question is what does paper trading offer you that a backtest doesn't?

text: It's happening in real time and with live data.  In theory it should be the same as backtesting, but who knows what errors you might have made that won't show up with historic data, but will in live data?  It's just a safety net to stop you losing a load of money.

elements.text: It's happening in real time and with live data.  In theory it should be the same as backtesting, but who knows what errors you might have made that won't show up with historic data, but will in live data?  It's just a safety net to stop you losing a load of money.

text: There might be other reasons for doing it, but I think that's the main one.

elements.text: There might be other reasons for doing it, but I think that's the main one.

text:
Interesting. I suppose I could see the value if the process/data for backtesting and live was different but in theory the available data should be identical right?
<@U01MPC0GUK1>, out of interest, do you use paper trading?

elements.text: Interesting. I suppose I could see the value if the process/data for backtesting and live was different but in theory the available data should be identical right?
, out of interest, do you use paper trading?

text:
Yeah, in theory it should be the same, and to be fair Flumine already has checks in-built to make it less likely that you'll blow your bank.  So you don't have to do it if you don't want to - up to you.

I've used it sparingly.  To be fair my process is a bit slap dash.  Rather than analysis -> backtest -> paper trade -> live, mine's make something up in my head that I think's logical -> back test it -> live -> analysis to refine it.

elements.text:

I've used it sparingly.  To be fair my process is a bit slap dash.  Rather than analysis -> backtest -> paper trade -> live, mine's make something up in my head that I think's logical -> back test it -> live -> analysis to refine it.

text: Yep it’s basically a final integration test that is using live data, handy if you are testing new markets where you don’t have data or in my case checking a change/update without accidentally fat fingering

elements.text: Yep it’s basically a final integration test that is using live data, handy if you are testing new markets where you don’t have data or in my case checking a change/update without accidentally fat fingering

text: <@U01SCPDTV5J> The data may be the same shape but the delivery method is different, so if a test is possible then the question becomes why not?  Personally I'd always do it for a while at least as it was a useful part of the belt and braces methodology I introduced at my old 'work'.  I like to treat my money with the same degree of respect I had to show towards other people's.:slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: The data may be the same shape but the delivery method is different, so if a test is possible then the question becomes why not?  Personally I'd always do it for a while at least as it was a useful part of the belt and braces methodology I introduced at my old 'work'.  I like to treat my money with the same degree of respect I had to show towards other people's.

text: The data isn't really the same shape. When backtesting Flumine processes one market at a time by default (unless you ask it to group markets together e.g. by event). With paper trading you're getting all the open markets captured by your filter, at the same time, so the same structure as your live strategy will see. This is especially useful if your strategy crosses markets.

elements.text: The data isn't really the same shape. When backtesting Flumine processes one market at a time by default (unless you ask it to group markets together e.g. by event). With paper trading you're getting all the open markets captured by your filter, at the same time, so the same structure as your live strategy will see. This is especially useful if your strategy crosses markets.

text: I'm considering getting a new computer. For backtesting and placing bets, does it make a noticeable difference whether you have 8 gig of RAM or 16 gig?

elements.text: I'm considering getting a new computer. For backtesting and placing bets, does it make a noticeable difference whether you have 8 gig of RAM or 16 gig?

text: <@U013K4VNB6D> 8GB is the lowest you would want to go and should be OKish. But if possible go for 16GB plus. More importantly make sure you get a SSD (solid state drive) as this will make a huge difference to the overall speed of your PC.

elements.text: 8GB is the lowest you would want to go and should be OKish. But if possible go for 16GB plus. More importantly make sure you get a SSD (solid state drive) as this will make a huge difference to the overall speed of your PC.
